title: Matt Rosendale
added: {{Main|2018 United States Senate election in Montana}}

title: Matt Rosendale
deleted: In 2017, Rosendale announced he would seek the Republican nomination to challenge two-term incumbent Democratic Senator [[Jon Tester]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=O'Brien|first=Edward|title=Matt Rosendale Announces Run For Montana Senate Seat|url=https://www.mtpr.org/post/matt-rosendale-announces-run-montana-senate-seat|access-date=2020-06-24|website=www.mtpr.org|language=en}}</ref>

In a competitive four-way primary, Rosendale faced [[U.S. district judge|District Judge]] [[Russell Fagg]], State Senator [[Albert Olszewski|Al Olszewski]], and [[combat veteran]] Troy Downing.<ref name=":2" /> Rosendale won the Republican primary with 33.8% of the vote, to Fagg's 28.3%, Downing's 19.1% and Olszewski's 18.7%.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Montana 2018 Statewide Primary Election Results|url=https://sosmt.gov/wp-content/uploads/2018-Primary-Official-Statewide-Canvass.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=|website=}}</ref>{{Election box begin no change|title=Republican primary results<ref name="Primary Election" />}}{{Election box winning candidate with party link no change|candidate=Matt Rosendale|party=Republican Party (United States)|votes=51,859|percentage=33.8%}}{{Election box candidate with party link no change|party=Republican Party (United States)|candidate=Russ Fagg|votes=43,465|percentage=28.3%}}{{Election box candidate with party link no change|party=Republican Party (United States)|candidate=Troy Downing|votes=29,341|percentage=19.1%}}{{Election box candidate with party link no change|party=Republican Party (United States)|candidate=Al Olszewski|votes=28,681|percentage=18.7%}}{{Election box total no change|votes=153,346|percentage=100.00%}}{{Election box end}}After the primary, Rosendale was endorsed by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]]<ref>{{Cite web|last=Oprysko|first=Caitlin|title=Trump boosts Rosendale in tight Montana Senate race|url=https://politi.co/2CuiGV3|access-date=2020-06-25|website=POLITICO|language=en}}</ref> and [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Mike Pence]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Vice President Mike Pence stumps for Rosendale in Kalispell; Tester campaigns in Missoula {{!}} 406 Politics {{!}} billingsgazette.com|url=https://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/govt-and-politics/vice-president-mike-pence-stumps-for-rosendale-in-kalispell-tester-campaigns-in-missoula/article_82f65fa7-bb15-54e9-aeee-74807f374959.html?mode=nowapp|access-date=2020-06-25|website=billingsgazette.com}}</ref> Trump visited the state to campaign for Rosendale four times,<ref>{{Cite web|date=2018-10-30|title=Trump to go to Montana for 4th rally for GOP Senate hopeful|url=https://apnews.com/a6d9cffc14694483a37588740226d046|access-date=2020-06-25|website=AP NEWS}}</ref> with Pence visiting three times.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Vice president to campaign for Rosendale in Kalispell|url=https://www.greatfallstribune.com/story/news/2018/11/01/vice-president-pence-campaign-rosendale-kalispell/1851365002/|access-date=2020-06-25|website=Great Falls Tribune|language=en}}</ref>

Polls showed the race in a statistical tie going into [[2018 United States Senate elections|election day]],<ref>{{Cite web|last=holly.michels@lee.net|first=HOLLY K. MICHELS|title=In final push to election day, Tester and Rosendale stay the course|url=https://helenair.com/news/government-and-politics/in-final-push-to-election-day-tester-and-rosendale-stay-the-course/article_32c02c05-75bb-566f-b0b1-2d5fe5f622a9.html|access-date=2020-06-25|website=Helena Independent Record|language=en}}</ref> in what was the most expensive election in Montana history, with more than $70 million spent on both sides.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2018-12-10|title=More than $70 million spent in Montana US Senate race|url=https://apnews.com/68d7dab124f44fbf91afe12695fc3d24|access-date=2020-06-24|website=AP NEWS}}</ref> Tester's campaign had a huge cash advantage, raising and spending $21 million to Rosendale's $6 million.<ref>{{Cite web|title=2018 Election United States Senate - Montana|url=https://www.fec.gov/data/elections/senate/MT/2018/|access-date=2020-06-25|website=FEC.gov|language=en}}</ref>

In the general election, Tester won 50.3% of the vote to Rosendale's 46.8%, with [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] candidate Rick Breckenridge taking 2.9%.<ref>{{cite web |title=Montana U.S. Senate Election Results |url=https://www.nytimes.com/elections/results/montana-senate |work=New York Times |accessdate=November 9, 2018}}</ref>

title: Matt Rosendale
deleted: In 2013, incumbent [[U.S. Representative|Representative]] [[Steve Daines]] announced that he would not seek re-election and would instead run for the [[United States Senate]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Dennison|first=Mike|title=Daines announces candidacy for U.S. Senate|url=https://missoulian.com/news/local/daines-announces-candidacy-for-u-s-senate/article_6ae615d0-4715-11e3-842d-0019bb2963f4.html|access-date=2020-06-24|website=missoulian.com|language=en}}</ref> Following this, Rosendale announced he would be running to succeed him in the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]]. In addition to Rosendale, the Republican field included former State Senators [[Ryan Zinke]] and [[Corey Stapleton]], State Representative [[Elsie Arntzen]], and [[real estate investor]] Drew Turiano.<ref>{{Cite web|title=United States House of Representatives elections in Montana, 2014|url=https://ballotpedia.org/United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections_in_Montana,_2014|access-date=2020-06-24|website=Ballotpedia|language=en}}</ref>

Rosendale came in third place with 28.8% of the vote, behind Zinke with 33.3% of the vote and [[Corey Stapleton|Stapleton]] with 29.3% of the vote. [[Elsie Arntzen|Arntzen]] and Turiano received 6.9% and 1.7% respectively.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Montana 2014 Statewide Primary Election Results|url=https://sosmt.gov/wp-content/uploads/attachments/2014-Primary-Official-Statewide-Canvass.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=|website=}}</ref>
